image.altText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers delivers the budget speech.

items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers delivers this year's federal budget, with a focus on cost of living and health. Follow live.

title.children: Treasurer says bulk billing changes are 'a centrepiece' of the budget

schema.headline: Federal budget 2023 live: Treasurer Jim Chalmers' speech reveals $40 fortnightly rise in JobSeeker, boost to bulk billing and rental assistance

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What do you want to know about the budget?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: We want to find out your burning questions about the budget and hear how it impacts you. Will it provide you with some reprieve or have you fallen through the cracks? We'll be using your responses to inform our budget coverage. Fill out the form in our story below to share your suggestions and our journalists may be in touch to investigate for either a TV, radio, digital or social media story.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Is an extra $40 per fortnight for those on Jobseeker enough?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody:
Asked if more doctors were likely to bulk bill as a result of tonight's announcements, the treasurer says they're expecting 11.6 million Australians to be able to access "investment in Medicare in the budget". Turning to the increase to Jobseeker, Mr Chalmers says they have to "strike a series of fine balances". Chalmers: We understand that there will be people who are saying $40 a fortnight is not enough. There will be some who will be saying it is too much. We think we've struck the right balance 
between what we can afford and taking into consideration the economic pressures in the economy.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Who can take the credit for the budget surplus?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Is it the current government, or its predecessor? That was the first question Jeremy Fernandez put to economist Chris Richardson from Rich Insight. He says there's another culprit behind the surprise $4.2 billion surplus. "This is not happening because of any decision of any government," Mr Richardson says. "It's war and inflation, they're  terrible, but they turn out to be  great for the budget, the lucky country, very lucky with its budget. "Now surplus, I'm not going to be surprised if it is a surplus next year as well. "Skinnier deficits, lower debt, and on the official figures, the long-term budgetary  challenge looks magically lots lower than it looked a handful of months ago."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Treasurer says budget designed to take pressure off cost of living, not add to inflation
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Jim Chalmers is speaking with the ABC's David Speers now. Asked if he could guarantee that the budget wouldn't lead to inflation or higher interest rates, the treasurer says "I don't speak on behalf of the Reserve Bank governor". Chalmers: The restraint we've shown and the investments in the supply side of the economy and the way we've targeted and staged our cost of living package is because inflation is the biggest challenge in our economy. This budget has been carefully calibrated and carefully designed to take the pressure off the cost-of-living, not add to inflation.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Don't get  too excited by the surplus — the government is expecting more deficits
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: We're hearing a lot about the surprise budget surplus of $4.2 billion this year — the first surplus in 15 years — but don't think we're back in black permanently. In its economic outlook, the budget is forecasting a deficit of $13.9 billion in the next financial year of 2023-23 — but that's an improvement of $30.1 billion since October. Those deficits will remain, but will be lower than what they had expected. Here's what the next four years look like in forward estimates: 2023-24 : -$13.9 billion 2024-25 : -$35.1 billion 2025-26 : -$36.6 billion 2026-27 : -$28.5 billion The government doesn't think we'll be completely out of deficit now until 2029-30.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Coming up — Treasurer Jim Chalmers to face questions about the budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: He'll be interviewed on the ABC shortly about some of the big announcements to come out of this year's federal budget. You can watch live using the stream at the top of the page, or follow along on the blog.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ‘Modest but meaningful’ revenue measures
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The treasurer says there are some measures the government are taking regarding revenue measures, they include: Tightening superannuation tax concessions for those with balances exceeding $3 million A 15 per cent global and domestic minimum tax for large multinational companies Changes to the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax, so that Australians receive a fairer return on the sale of our natural resources, sooner Raising the tax on tobacco by 5 per cent for 3 years Extending tax compliance programs

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Your fast thoughts on what we've heard from the budget so far
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: If you've got a question or a comment, you can send them in using the big blue button at the top of the page. Great for the agedcare workforce. What about other low paid workers? Laundry workers? Pharmacy assistants? Some earning under $24 per hour. — Mimi Still not enough. 20 dollars a week how will this help with the cost of living. Better than nothing. — Janice Wonderful news on the bulk billing incentives! — Jaimie A lot of aged care workers won't be getting a 15% pay rise as they are paid above the award rate. I know a lot of my colleagues are going to angry because their pay will only increase by 8%. Also I'm still on the NSW State award and ergo locked in legally to only a 2.5% increase — Nat

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Rent support for low-income households
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: More than 1 million households will receive additional income support as the government increases the maximum rate of Commonwealth Rent Assistance by 15 per cent. It's the largest increase to the scheme in 30 years. Minister for Housing and Homelessness Julie Collins says low-income households who rent will benefit from the investment of $2.7 billion over five years. "These new budget measures complement the decisions taken by national cabinet to develop reforms to increase housing supply and affordability, and put renters' rights front and centre, with states and territories committing to work to strengthen renters' rights," Collins says.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Here's what's in the budget for businesses
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: As expected, there isn't a huge amount in the budget for businesses with the focus instead on households and those on welfare and low incomes to help with the cost of living. Small businesses will be pleased to see the instant asset write-off extended again for another year, but it's now limited at $20,000 on the value of any single asset. In other words, it's no longer big enough for a tradie to buy a new ute. The government is also getting the ATO to cut small businesses some slack in a few different ways that'll be helpful for their cashflow, but the payback is a continued crackdown on GST avoidance. You can read the takeaways from my colleagues, business reporters Michael Janda, Stephanie Chalmers and David Chau here:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Treasurer says aged care workers 'deserve every cent' of 15pc wage increase
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Jim Chalmers says he is proud that the budget will see more than 250,000 aged care workers see a substantial increase in their award wages, at a cost of $11.3 billion. "This pay rise will help retain, reward and recruit the hard-working people who care for our loved ones as they grow old," he says. "And the message from our government to the aged care workers of Australia is simple — you deserve every cent."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Treasurer says bulk billing changes are 'a centrepiece' of the budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Jim Chalmers says the budget includes "the largest increase to the bulk billing incentive, ever", to help strengthen Australia's health system. "A $3.5 billion boost that will help GPs provide free consultations to around 11.6 million eligible Australians, including children, pensioners and other concession card holders," he says in his budget speech. "All of this will help take pressure off our public hospitals and emergency departments, still feeling the strain of a once-in-a-century pandemic. "And it will ensure that for millions of people, the quality of your healthcare is guaranteed not by your credit card — but by your Medicare card."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The government says it will be easier and cheaper to see a doctor
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The government is investing $3.5 billion over five years so that it's cheaper and easier for millions of Australians to see a doctor. Bulk billing incentives will be tripled for the most common consultations with: Children under the age of 16 Pensioners Other commonwealth      concession card holders It will apply to face-to-face, telehealth and videoconference consultations. Health Minister Mark Butler says the government is tripling the incentives "to address the sharp decline in bulk billing over the past few years." "It will have immediate benefits for more than 11 million, with flow-on benefits for all Australians," Butler says.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Treasurer says JobSeeker increase will 'help those who need it the most'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Jim Chalmers says the increase to JobSeeker payments are needed to support around 1.1 million Australians who are looking for work, studying, or doing apprenticeships, despite "acute" pressures on the budget. On increasing JobSeeker payments for those aged over 55, he says the move will support "the single biggest group of Australians on JobSeeker". "Until now, people aged 60 and over and on payments for a long time have received a higher rate, in recognition of the additional barriers they face finding work," he says. "But the truth is, it gets more difficult earlier than that. The majority of people aged 55 and over on JobSeeker are women, many with little to no savings or superannuation, and who are at risk of homelessness."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Jobseeker, youth allowance and Austudy recipients will receive an extra $40 per fortnight
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: It’s been confirmed in the budget papers, an extra $40 per fortnight will be delivered for JobSeeker, youth allowance and Austudy recipients. It also applies to people who receive the parenting payment (partnered), ABSTUDY, disability support pension (youth) and special benefit. Over five years, the government will provide $4.9 billion to increase the support. As foreshadowed ahead of the budget, the treasurer also announced increased support for Jobseeker recipients aged 55 and older. Additional payments that were available for people aged 60 and older will now be extended to those aged over 55 .

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Aged care workers will see their largest pay rise ever
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The government is allocating $11.3 billion to provide aged care workers with an interim increase of 15 per cent to award wages. This was released ahead of the budget, but it is the largest increase to award wages for aged care workers ever. The government says it recognises the "complex and previously undervalued" work of the aged care workforce. Health Minister Mark Butler says this budget improves care, transparency and accountability in the sector. "Aged care workers have been undervalued and underpaid for too long – we are supporting a wage increase for them because it's the right thing to do," Butler says.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Increases to JobSeeker and welfare payments to assist with living costs
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: A modest increase in unemployment benefits and cheaper healthcare are the centrepieces of a federal budget tasked with helping the nation's most vulnerable as living costs continue to hurt households. Treasurer Jim Chalmers' second budget, which forecasts a surplus this year, seeks to tackle women's inequality, reduce inflation and lay the foundations for growth as the global economy slows. The budget sees the JobSeeker unemployment rate rise $2.80 a day, rent assistance increase up to $15 a week and single parents will be $380 a month better off. Surging commodity prices and low unemployment have bolstered the bottom line but the treasurer is warning that tougher days are still on the horizon. You can read the main takeaways from the budget from political correspondent Brett Worthington here:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Treasurer says cost-of-living relief is the budget's 'number-one priority'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Jim Chalmers says the "number-one priority" of his budget is $14.6 billion of cost-of-living relief, which he says has been designed to not make inflation worse than it already is. The treasurer says the relief measures will include: Help with power bills Reduced health costs Creating more affordable      housing Increasing wages and      supporting the most vulnerable Chalmers says inflation is still "our primary economic challenge". "In all our decisions, we seek to strike a considered, methodical balance. Between spending restraint to keep the pressure off inflation, while doing what we can to help people struggling to make ends meet," he says. He says the government's policies will take three-quarters of a percentage point off inflation in 2023-24, keeping the country tracking "in the right direction".

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Treasurer says a slowing global economy will continue to impact Australia
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: According to the government, economic growth over the next two years is expected to be weak. The global economy is forecast to slow considerably this year and pick up modestly in 2024. The treasurer says Australia isn't immune from "persistent inflation, higher interest rates and financial sector strains" around the world, which will impact Australia's growth potential. "Our economic growth is expected to slow from 3.25 per cent in 2022–23 to 1.5 per cent the year after, before recovering to 2.25 per cent in the next," he says. "Despite this, our economy will continue to create jobs, and unemployment is expected to remain low by historical standards — 4.25 per cent in 2023–24, 4.5 per cent the year after."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is speaking
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers is now delivering his budget speech. It's titled "stronger foundations for a better future". He's going to touch on a bunch of measures in the budget, including: Cost-of-living relief Medicare investments Clean energy A budget surplus He says the budget lays the foundation for "building a stronger economy and a fairer society." You can watch the live stream at the top of our blog.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: The federal budget has been released
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Hello! The budget papers have been released (and so have I from lock-up), I have so much to catch you up on. There are announcements for Medicare, JobSeeker payments, aged care, and cost-of-living support. But there’s also no indication the economy is going to make a recovery from persistent inflation and high interest rates anytime soon. Let’s jump right into what Treasurer Jim Chalmers is announcing.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Find out if you're among the budget's winners or losers
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: More money for JobSeeker, bulk billing and spies, but more taxes on smokers and travellers. Find out who is up and who is down in the second federal budget delivered by Treasurer Jim Chalmers.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Jim Chalmers is delivering his budget address
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: My colleagues Shiloh Payne and Tom Williams have just been released from the lock-up and will bring you the best bits from the Treasurer's speech. You can watch live now using the livestream pinned to the top of this page.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Your thoughts on this year's federal budget — and what you're hoping for
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: We're now just 10 minutes away from the budget reveal. If you've got a question or a comment, you can send it in using the big blue button at the top of the page. Let see if this budget is a step to solve long standing problems or pretend they can be solved later in the name of "we're in a crisis so other things take priority." — Josh I'm a widowed mother with two teens. The youngest is 14, so I'm out of of luck there. I have an investment property (but the tenants have stopped paying rent) so my assets are too high to get Jobseeker. I can't work at the moment because my child is being relentlessly bullied at school, so any time, without warning, I've got to go deal with that. We're surviving on family benefits, which is far less than Jobseeker. There's literally nothing in the budget for me and no relief in sight. — Not Enough I'm interested to hear about updates regarding the increase in the cap for stamp duty for new home owners I.e. stamp duty is waived for properties up to $800k. — Carole Fingers crossed they finally announce some details on the "Help to buy" scheme. They've gone very silent on it since last budget. — Crenn

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Want an economist's take on the budget?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: You and me both! But what if I told you that you could get two economists getting into the nitty gritty about what the budget means for the economy? Interested? I thought so (you are on a budget live blog, after all). Look no further than the special half-hour of The Business dedicated to all things budget at 9:30pm AEST, where host Kathryn Robinson will be joined on the panel by the ABC's business editor Ian Verrender, Barrenjoey chief economist Jo Masters, and e61 Institute research manager Lachlan Vass. Still need convincing? I'll let my colleagues do the talking.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Energy relief is coming — but experts waiting for details of who and how
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By social affairs correspondent Norman Hermant Treasurer Jim Chalmers has confirmed the government will deliver energy bill relief in the budget. He says 5.5 million households that are receiving pensions and other government payments, as well as around a million small businesses, will be eligible. There are some reports it could total up to $500 per household. One thing to watch out for is an indication from the government about how this relief will be delivered. Experts such as Nicola Willand, a researcher in housing and sustainability at RMIT University, say the most effective form of delivery will be direct payments from the government into retail energy accounts. Dr Willand also hopes any energy payment isn’t limited to those receiving pensions and Centrelink benefits, “as low-income families just above welfare may miss out”. But while bill relief may be welcome short-term help, it’s not a long-term fix to high energy prices. “It’s going to help a lot, but it’s not going to be a sustainable solution,” Dr Willand said. She believes future spending initiatives should be focused on retrofitting homes to make them more energy efficient. “Homes are not well insulated, they’re not draft-proof, heaters are not efficient. Retrofitting offers continued relief.”

liveBlogUpdate.headline: We're now just 30 minutes away from the federal budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: At 7:30pm AEST, Treasurer Jim Chalmers will deliver his budget speech — you can watch that live using the YouTube stream pinned to the top of the page. At the same time, our team of reporters will be released from the lock-up, so stay tuned for further details on some of those announcements and what they could mean for you.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What major infrastructure projects are getting the budget green light?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: What large infrastructure projects does the 2023 budget support? What states are the winners? - Anna. Hey Anna, thanks for the question. We haven't heard much about major infrastructure projects yet, but there's one big one that you've probably heard about: a new stadium in Hobart. Last weekend Prime Minister Anthony Albanese confirmed the federal government would chip in $240 million towards the $715 million fixed-roof stadium to be built at Macquarie Point, which was the final hurdle for Tasmania to get their own AFL team. I'd say we can expect a few more major infrastructure projects being funded — alas, I have not been locked up with the mountains of budget papers this afternoon so I cannot say for sure. (Side note: C'monnnn, 7:30pm!)

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What cost-of-living relief to look out for in the budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By social affairs correspondent Norman Hermant and the Specialist Reporting Team’s Leonie Thorne Two hours before the budget drops, the government has come out and confirmed something we basically already knew: JobSeeker payments will be getting a boost. What we didn’t know was which job seekers would benefit and by how much exactly their payments would increase. The 5:00pm announcement has done virtually nothing to clarify that, beyond saying the JobSeeker base rate will increase. About a week ago, we started seeing reports that job seekers over 55 were set to get a boost to their weekly payments. Treasurer Jim Chalmers did not deny those reports. More recently, there have also been leaks suggesting that JobSeeker recipients under 55 could receive modest increases too — about $20 extra per week. The 5pm pre-budget announcement has not confirmed this either. Some advocates, such as Kristin O’Connell from the Antipoverty Centre, believe the later leaks came about after the government was criticised for considering limiting increases to those aged over 55. “The 20 bucks [per week] is a thought bubble,” Ms O’Connell said. “Everything they’ve done in the last week around social security is them being totally taken aback by the reaction.” Advocates also point out that even if these boosts to JobSeeker do materialise, the payment will remain well below the poverty line. Currently, the JobSeeker payment for a single person is $693 a fortnight.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Could tonight's budget make inflation worse?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: It's a reasonable question to ask — and if you're anything like me (read: an economics fanatic) you'll have heard plenty of questions being thrown around whether this year's budget is inflationary. Unfortunately it's a bit *too* complicated to answer in short, but let's unpack why you're going to be hearing this phrase and what it means. We know the budget lays out the government's spending intentions for the year (and beyond) and they are hyper-focused on providing cost of living relief because as the name suggests, it's costing us more to live, thanks to higher than average inflation and higher interest rates. The Reserve Bank is using higher interest rates to tackle inflation by deterring us from spending — because the more we spend, the more we add to inflation — but the problem is that the prices of things we need (think housing, energy, food) are also going up. That's partly due to inflation and interest rates, but it's also due to supply shocks thanks to COVID and the Ukraine war, and the price of imported goods being high thanks to the price of our Aussie dollar. Add to that a growing population and housing shortage, and you start to get a sense of how many factors the government is contending with in preparing the budget. Obviously this is a highly simplified version, but it gives us an idea of just how complicated it is. Now when you factor in government spending to keep things ticking over, and how broad a range that is, you can see why the concerns start to mount about an inflationary budget. (Bear in mind, the government also needs to *borrow* money to make all of this happen — and that money needs to be paid back at higher interest rates.) Of course, these things are necessary to keep our country going, and plenty of people argue that the cost of living measures are needed to help people survive — which is why you're hearing Treasurer Jim Chalmers say that they have been carefully considering every measure in the budget to make sure it's not going to make inflation worse. As for how they've reached that balance? We'll hear the justification in less than an hour from now — and we'll also be getting economic experts to unpack it all too.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Patricia Karvelas: 'It's the things we don't know yet that will fascinate me'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: As we've heard a bit this evening, cost-of-living relief and health will be major features in this year's budget. The ABC's Patricia Karvelas dropped by the blog a little earlier with some of the things she'll be keeping an eye on: Patricia : A federal budget is a big marketing exercise for any government - a chance to make key decisions and choices that demonstrate values and priorities. Journalists are locked up to pore over papers for hours and the government attempts to spin and sell their decisions. And so as we enter Jim Chalmer’s second budget the two political narratives the government has sought to run are that it will engage in fiscal discipline — trying to rewrite the script that Labor is reckless with money — and targeted cost-of-living relief to help the country’s most desperate people. But it’s the things we don’t yet know that will fascinate me. One element will be just how targeted the support for those on welfare will be? Another is housing — it’s the number one water cooler topic in this country. How much will the government invest in tackling some of the entrenched issues. And finally, I will be studying budget paper number 2. That’s the budget paper where you find all the cuts! Finance Minister Katy Gallagher has announced $17.8 billion in “savings” that will contribute to the substantial cost-of-living package, I want to know what will be slashed. That tells a story too — about the things the new government doesn’t value. Looking for more? Patricia Karvelas will be interviewing Anthony Albanese tomorrow at 7:35am on ABC RN Patricia: At 7.35am I’ll be interviewing the Prime Minister which really is a key interview for me - and him. How does he handle some of the curly questions on how all this money being pushed out the door will impact on inflation? And what story about him and his government does he want to tell?

liveBlogUpdate.headline: How does the budget process work?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: If you don't know what a lock-up is, don't worry, I'm here to explain. A media lock-up is essentially when a group of journalists are given sensitive information early for the purpose of reporting, but they're locked in a restricted space with no internet to stop any information from leaking early. In the case of the federal budget, there are strict processes where the Treasury approves your attendance ahead of time and officials are there on the day to monitor your activity. We're given the budget papers so that when Treasurer Jim Chalmers reveals this year's budget, we can quickly report on what it means for you. They also take our phones away from us so it's also a bit of an unintentional digital detox.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Rent assistance boost confirmed — but advocates hope it’s enough
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: With rents reaching record highs in Australia, advocates are hoping to see some relief for low-income households. The ABC's social affairs correspondent Norman Hermant joins us with more: Norman: The government confirmed tonight that rent assistance would increase, so we’re just waiting to see more details. About 1.5 million households receive the Commonwealth Rent Assistance payment. Most of those households are on pensions and benefits. It currently pays a maximum of $157 a fortnight for singles whose rent is between $140 and $350 per week. The Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) has recommended that payment be doubled. In a recent report, ACOSS noted 93 per cent of people renting privately were in rental stress, spending more than 30 per cent of their income on rent. If it is boosted, it could be considered a win for beleaguered renters.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What's in the budget for small businesses?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: We know cost-of-living relief is front and centre for this budget for both the government and everyday Aussies, but there's another group who are top of mind for Treasurer Jim Chalmers: small businesses. They're are also going to be watching very closely tonight — they're being squeezed from all sides when it comes to inflation, rising interest rates, high energy prices, supply chain blockages and staff shortages. One major policy coming out of the budget that we already know about that's been targeted towards a million small business owners is the energy rebate, that makes up part of the government's $14.6 billion cost of living package, unveiled yesterday. That will be welcome relief for many small business owners, according to MYOB's chief employee experience officer and government policy lead Helen Lea, who says small businesses are battling a "perfect storm" in the wake of COVID. She's eager for the budget to contain measures that encourage digital innovation — "because we know digital businesses are moer productive," she told RN Breakfast host Patricia Karvelas. As for what other measures there might be for small business owners? We'll have to wait for all to be revealed at 7:30pm. In the meantime, you can hear Ms Lea's full chat below:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What's in the budget for those under 30?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Not only are under 30s contending with the same cost-of-living pressures being felt across the country, but young Aussies are also hard hit by housing issues. The ABC's political reporter Claudia Long dropped by the blog a little earlier this afternoon to help unpack it all: Claudia: The federal government has its work cut out for it if they plan to use this budget to show young people they're important to Labor. Not only are under 30s contending with the same spiralling cost of living pressures as the rest of the country, young Australians are hard hit by issues around housing. Aside from the often completely out of reach task of buying a home, getting access to rent assistance isn't as straightforward when you're living in a sharehouse — something that isn't confined to under 30's but is certainly more common. And the rising price of pretty much everything hits even harder when you've barely had a chance to establish any savings if you've made it into the workforce. The federal government says they're going to be prioritising the most vulnerable if this budget, at 7:30pm tonight under 30s get to find out whether that includes them.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Hopes budget will give more detail on 'disappointing' NDIS target
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By the specialist teporting team’s Leonie Thorne Last month Disability Services Minister Bill Shorten said the agency responsible for supporting Australians with disability had "lost its way" and needed significant work to ensure its survival. Advocates hope tonight's budget will shed more light on what that "work" involves. The government has already announced a new growth target, which would save more than $50 billion from the NDIS over the next decade. Spending on the scheme was projected to grow about 14 per cent annually over the next decade. The new target will limit that to 8 per cent by 2026. We also know the government is planning to crack down on price-gouging NDIS providerswho overcharge people with disability. "If you have a business model where you are mining someone's supported independent living package for your own interests … sell your business now, because it's not going to be worth much by the time we're finished with you," Mr Shorten told reporters a few weeks ago. The government is also allocating more than $720 million over four years to overhaul the NDIA — the agency which runs the NDIS. What we DON'T know is how the government plans to limit the NDIS's growth, and what changes participants can expect. Disability advocates were shocked and “disappointed” by the growth target, saying they were blindsided by the announcement. Many people in the disability sector are also tired of discourse around reining in the cost of the NDIS, saying it should instead be seen as an investment that has changed the lives of thousands of Australians for the better.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: This year's budget brings good news for single parents
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese yesterday announced an expansion to the single parent payment worth $1.9 billion over the next four years. The ABC's political reporter Tahlia Roy joins us, and says the budget measure will see single parents supported until their youngest dependent turns 14. Tahlia: It is slated to take effect from September 20 and will see an additional 57,000 single parents able to access more than $900 per fortnight. In 2006, the Howard Coalition government changed the eligibility requirements for the payment, lowering the age limit from 16 to eight years old. The decision was grandfathered, so people already on the scheme could remain on it. The Gillard Labor government in 2012 scrapped the grandfathering, moving people with a child older than 8 but younger than 16 onto an unemployment benefit.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Expected budget surplus not expected to last, economist says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The federal government is forecasting a small budget surplus of about $4 billion this financial year, the first in 15 years. The dramatic turnaround from the $36.9 billion deficit projected in October has been driven by high commodity prices, a strong jobs market and a boost in net migration. But Stephen Koukoulas of Market Economics says the federal budget surplus is not expected to last. Stephen: Key commodities that delivered that surging company profit tax have already started to weaken. So that's going to put a hole in future government revenue. And of course, the government is delivering on its election promises from last year. Things like the childcare payments, the increase in the Jobseeker amounts of funding.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What are you hoping for out of the federal budget?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: I can't help feeling this'll be the Beatles Budget; "We all wanna buy a nuclear submarine, in case there is a war, otherwise for no reason at all! We all wanna buy a nuclear submarine, in case there is a war, otherwise for no reason at all, ..." Will those subs even get a mention tonight? If we're headed for a modest Govt surplus, just for this year, does that mean we haven't started to pay for these toys yet? Our sub's are on lay-by? - Big Ben. Thanks for writing in Ben, we're all keen to hear the finer details from the budget at 7:30pm AEDT (and as a reminder, you can watch live using the stream at the top of the page). If you're reading along and have a question or comment, you can send in your thoughts using the big blue button at the top of the page.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Students protest outside Parliament House ahead of federal budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: They're calling on the federal government to listen to the concerns of young people ahead of tonight's budget, including wiping student debt and changing the age of independence. President of the National Union of Students, Bailey Riley, says the age should be lowered from 22 to 18. Bailey : So that's when you're considered independent from your parents, and it's a bit weird, because when you're 18 you can drink, you can drive, you can legally be arrested, you're basically considered an adult except for Centrelink. So over 450,000 students are locked out from Youth Allowance and Austudy payments because of the age of independence.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Labor’s green election pledges will cost money. Here are the environmental promises to keep an eye out for
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By national environment and science reporter Michael Slezak Environment funding has been slashed since 2013. If the government wants to halt the extinction crisis — as it said it did during the election — that needs to change. For context, Australia currently holds the crowning achievement of having more mammal extinctions than any other continent. With that in mind, here are some things we’re keeping an eye out for in tonight’s budget: Environment law reform : This was a central part of the government’s election platform, so we’re looking to see what money goes towards the promised new federal Environmental Protection Authority, and what funding there is to get the environmental laws rewritten Water policy: We’re expecting to see some money for water market reform, and also looking out for funding for a promised review of the Murray Darling Basin Plan Local waterways: Speaking of water, Labor also promised to help clean up local waterways through a new “Urban Rivers and Catchments Program”. We’re looking out for funding for that too Threatened species : Last October, Labor announced a zero extinctions target – so we might see a little bit of extra money go towards some threatened species programs Nature markets: The government also has the big “Nature Repair Market” program, which aims to entice businesses to invest in nature ( read more about the debate here ). We’re expecting to see some funding for that

liveBlogUpdate.headline: How well do you know your federal budget trivia?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: If you're anything like me, not at all. While we wait for tonight's announcements, put your skills to the test!

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What can we expect for childcare in the budget?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Making childcare cheaper was one of Anthony Albanese's promises as he went into the last election. So what can we expect for the families in this year's budget? Political reporter Nour Haydar has more: Nour: Anthony Albanese went to the last election with a pledge to “make childcare cheaper” and the changes Labor promised will soon kick in. From July 2023, more than 1.2 million families will be able to access higher childcare subsidies. Under legislation that has already been passed by the parliament, families earning $80,000 or less will get 90 percent of the childcare fees subsidised. Higher subsidy rates will also apply for families earning under $530,000. The government says the changes will benefit 96 per cent of families with a child in early childhood education and care and will cost $55 billion over the next four years to 2026-27.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: How are the budget papers released?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The members of media in budget lock-ups are given access to the budget papers about six hours early and spend that time planning our coverage for you. In this case, the lock-up ends at 7.30 pm, when Treasurer Jim Chalmers will deliver his budget speech (and we'll get our internet access back). That time is when I'll be joining you right here to let you know everything I've found out over that six hours. Once his budget speech is over, the treasurer will join the ABC's federal budget television special for an interview. We'll also have an interview with the shadow treasurer, Angus Taylor.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Will the budget deliver on Medicare promises?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: In healthcare, one of the big things to watch for tonight will be Medicare. The specialist reporting team's Penny Timms is here to help sort through it all: Penny: You might remember that last year, the federal government asked a team of experts to put their heads together and come up with recommendations on how to improve access to primary care and reduce the load on hospitals. Their Strengthening Medicare report, released in February, called for a rethink of how Australia funds primary care and GPs – but did not result in any immediate announcements. At the time, medical experts criticised the report for not including enough detail. So, a lot of people in healthcare will be looking out for the Strengthening Medicare Taskforce’s suggested reforms, and detail on how they will actually happen. The government has talked a big game, and if it doesn't do much, that is likely to be a talking point. During the election, Labor promised close to $1 billion for Medicare and GPs. Of that cash, $750 million was earmarked for the Strengthening Medicare scheme. Now the healthcare sector is waiting to see how it’s spent. One other area to watch is whether this budget will include funding for the promised Centre for Disease Control (CDC), which would better prepare Australia for national health emergencies. Last year’s October “mini-budget” included $3.2 million for “preparations to establish” the CDC. The government and health advocates have already flagged such a centre would require significant additional funding.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Finance Minister Katy Gallagher on what will be in the budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The federal budget is set to include almost $15 billion in cost-of-living relief, amid a year where high inflation continues to take its toll. Speaking to ABC News Breakfast, Finance Minister Katy Gallagher said it's a "significant package". Kate Gallagher : Not just in the scale, but in the reach that we're trying to have with it. So, you know, you'll see different measures as part of that cost of living package. But I think what it shows is that, that really has been front and center our thinking as we finalise the budget... How to provide that sensible and affordable cost of living relief against, you know, an environment of high inflation and that's been certainly a challenge as we've been making our decisions, but people will see the full details of that.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: About 5 million households are expected to receive up to $500 in power bill relief in the budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The support is expected to be aimed at pensioners, others on government payments and small businesses. The ABC's political reporter Tom Lowrey joins us, and says it's likely the relief will come in the form of subsidies on energy bills, as opposed to direct payments to households: Tom: For months the federal government has been talking up energy price relief as a “centrepiece” of the budget, and tonight they will finally put some detail to the rhetoric. $1.5bn was pledged in December to help Australians push their power bills down, which would be matched by the states and territories. It’s expected tonight’s package will see roughly 5 million households, and 1 million businesses, receive up to $500 in relief from their power bills. The support is expected to primarily be targeted at pensioners, others on government payments and small businesses. It’s also likely that rather than being paid directly to households, the relief will come as subsidies on energy bills. But the arrangements could become quite complex, as the federal government coordinates its package with various state and territory governments, and energy retailers.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: G'Day from budget lock-up
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Hi everyone, Shiloh here! I've been sent off to the ABC's federal budget lockup. When you're reading this, I've probably already been locked in a room with no internet access for several hours, but don't worry, I'm not breaking any rules, I prepared this blog post for you earlier today. While Bridget is taking you through what we're expecting and what it will all mean for you, I'm trawling through the budget papers with a fine-tooth comb alongside a bunch of my colleagues. You'll hear from me throughout the blog, and I'll be bursting out of the lock-up at 7.30 pm to join you live and tell you everything there is to know about this year's budget.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Increase in JobSeeker and rent assistance confirmed ahead of tonight's federal budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: In news just in, the government has confirmed that tonight's federal budget will include an increase to the JobSeeker base rate, rent assistance, Austudy and Youth Allowance. The JobSeeker payment currently sits at around $50 a day, while youth allowance is $40 a day. The government has promised a $14.6 billion cost-of-living relief package, targeting "the most vulnerable Australians". Earlier today, Treasurer Jim Chalmers said the relief is "broader than what has been speculated on." Chalmers: It has a number of elements, it won't all be limited by age or by other distinctions. There will be help for the most vulnerable, but also for middle Australia.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Welcome to our live coverage of the 2023 federal budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Good afternoon and thanks for joining our live coverage of this year's federal budget. Very shortly I'll be joined by my blog co-hosts, Shiloh Payne, who'll have the latest out of lock-up, and business reporter Kate Ainsworth, who is here to help navigate what tonight's announcements mean for the economy, housing and more. Throughout this evening, we'll also hear from our team of political reporters in Canberra and journalists from across the country about what the budget means for you. At 7:30pm AEDT, you can watch the Treasurer's speech live using the stream at the top of the page. Until then, if you've got any questions or thoughts about this year's federal budget, use the blue Leave a Comment button above to send them in.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Is it the current government, or its predecessor? That was the first question Jeremy Fernandez put to economist Chris Richardson from Rich Insight. He says there's another culprit behind the surprise $4.2 billion surplus. "This is not happening because of any decision of any government," Mr Richardson says. "It's war and inflation, they're  terrible, but they turn out to be  great for the budget, the lucky country, very lucky with its budget. "Now surplus, I'm not going to be surprised if it is a surplus next year as well. "Skinnier deficits, lower debt, and on the official figures, the long-term budgetary  challenge looks magically lots lower than it looked a handful of months ago."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Who can take the credit for the budget surplus?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jim Chalmers is speaking with the ABC's David Speers now. Asked if he could guarantee that the budget wouldn't lead to inflation or higher interest rates, the treasurer says "I don't speak on behalf of the Reserve Bank governor". Chalmers: The restraint we've shown and the investments in the supply side of the economy and the way we've targeted and staged our cost of living package is because inflation is the biggest challenge in our economy. This budget has been carefully calibrated and carefully designed to take the pressure off the cost-of-living, not add to inflation.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer says budget designed to take pressure off cost of living, not add to inflation

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're hearing a lot about the surprise budget surplus of $4.2 billion this year — the first surplus in 15 years — but don't think we're back in black permanently. In its economic outlook, the budget is forecasting a deficit of $13.9 billion in the next financial year of 2023-23 — but that's an improvement of $30.1 billion since October. Those deficits will remain, but will be lower than what they had expected. Here's what the next four years look like in forward estimates: 2023-24 : -$13.9 billion 2024-25 : -$35.1 billion 2025-26 : -$36.6 billion 2026-27 : -$28.5 billion The government doesn't think we'll be completely out of deficit now until 2029-30.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Don't get  too excited by the surplus — the government is expecting more deficits

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More than 1 million households will receive additional income support as the government increases the maximum rate of Commonwealth Rent Assistance by 15 per cent. It's the largest increase to the scheme in 30 years. Minister for Housing and Homelessness Julie Collins says low-income households who rent will benefit from the investment of $2.7 billion over five years. "These new budget measures complement the decisions taken by national cabinet to develop reforms to increase housing supply and affordability, and put renters' rights front and centre, with states and territories committing to work to strengthen renters' rights," Collins says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rent support for low-income households

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As expected, there isn't a huge amount in the budget for businesses with the focus instead on households and those on welfare and low incomes to help with the cost of living. Small businesses will be pleased to see the instant asset write-off extended again for another year, but it's now limited at $20,000 on the value of any single asset. In other words, it's no longer big enough for a tradie to buy a new ute. The government is also getting the ATO to cut small businesses some slack in a few different ways that'll be helpful for their cashflow, but the payback is a continued crackdown on GST avoidance. You can read the takeaways from my colleagues, business reporters Michael Janda, Stephanie Chalmers and David Chau here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Here's what's in the budget for businesses

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jim Chalmers says he is proud that the budget will see more than 250,000 aged care workers see a substantial increase in their award wages, at a cost of $11.3 billion. "This pay rise will help retain, reward and recruit the hard-working people who care for our loved ones as they grow old," he says. "And the message from our government to the aged care workers of Australia is simple — you deserve every cent."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jim Chalmers says the budget includes "the largest increase to the bulk billing incentive, ever", to help strengthen Australia's health system. "A $3.5 billion boost that will help GPs provide free consultations to around 11.6 million eligible Australians, including children, pensioners and other concession card holders," he says in his budget speech. "All of this will help take pressure off our public hospitals and emergency departments, still feeling the strain of a once-in-a-century pandemic. "And it will ensure that for millions of people, the quality of your healthcare is guaranteed not by your credit card — but by your Medicare card."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer says bulk billing changes are 'a centrepiece' of the budget

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The government is investing $3.5 billion over five years so that it's cheaper and easier for millions of Australians to see a doctor. Bulk billing incentives will be tripled for the most common consultations with: Children under the age of 16 Pensioners Other commonwealth      concession card holders It will apply to face-to-face, telehealth and videoconference consultations. Health Minister Mark Butler says the government is tripling the incentives "to address the sharp decline in bulk billing over the past few years." "It will have immediate benefits for more than 11 million, with flow-on benefits for all Australians," Butler says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jim Chalmers says the increase to JobSeeker payments are needed to support around 1.1 million Australians who are looking for work, studying, or doing apprenticeships, despite "acute" pressures on the budget. On increasing JobSeeker payments for those aged over 55, he says the move will support "the single biggest group of Australians on JobSeeker". "Until now, people aged 60 and over and on payments for a long time have received a higher rate, in recognition of the additional barriers they face finding work," he says. "But the truth is, it gets more difficult earlier than that. The majority of people aged 55 and over on JobSeeker are women, many with little to no savings or superannuation, and who are at risk of homelessness."

It also applies to people who receive the parenting payment (partnered), ABSTUDY, disability support pension (youth) and special benefit. Over five years, the government will provide $4.9 billion to increase the support. As foreshadowed ahead of the budget, the treasurer also announced increased support for Jobseeker recipients aged 55 and older. Additional payments that were available for people aged 60 and older will now be extended to those aged over 55 .

This was released ahead of the budget, but it is the largest increase to award wages for aged care workers ever. The government says it recognises the "complex and previously undervalued" work of the aged care workforce. Health Minister Mark Butler says this budget improves care, transparency and accountability in the sector. "Aged care workers have been undervalued and underpaid for too long – we are supporting a wage increase for them because it's the right thing to do," Butler says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A modest increase in unemployment benefits and cheaper healthcare are the centrepieces of a federal budget tasked with helping the nation's most vulnerable as living costs continue to hurt households. Treasurer Jim Chalmers' second budget, which forecasts a surplus this year, seeks to tackle women's inequality, reduce inflation and lay the foundations for growth as the global economy slows. The budget sees the JobSeeker unemployment rate rise $2.80 a day, rent assistance increase up to $15 a week and single parents will be $380 a month better off. Surging commodity prices and low unemployment have bolstered the bottom line but the treasurer is warning that tougher days are still on the horizon. You can read the main takeaways from the budget from political correspondent Brett Worthington here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Increases to JobSeeker and welfare payments to assist with living costs

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jim Chalmers says the "number-one priority" of his budget is $14.6 billion of cost-of-living relief, which he says has been designed to not make inflation worse than it already is. The treasurer says the relief measures will include: Help with power bills Reduced health costs Creating more affordable      housing Increasing wages and      supporting the most vulnerable Chalmers says inflation is still "our primary economic challenge". "In all our decisions, we seek to strike a considered, methodical balance. Between spending restraint to keep the pressure off inflation, while doing what we can to help people struggling to make ends meet," he says. He says the government's policies will take three-quarters of a percentage point off inflation in 2023-24, keeping the country tracking "in the right direction".

Reduced health costs
Creating more affordable      housing
Increasing wages and      supporting the most vulnerable
Chalmers says inflation is still "our primary economic challenge".

"In all our decisions, we seek to strike a considered, methodical balance. Between spending restraint to keep the pressure off inflation, while doing what we can to help people struggling to make ends meet," he says.
He says the government's policies will take three-quarters of a percentage point off inflation in 2023-24, keeping the country tracking "in the right direction".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: According to the government, economic growth over the next two years is expected to be weak. The global economy is forecast to slow considerably this year and pick up modestly in 2024. The treasurer says Australia isn't immune from "persistent inflation, higher interest rates and financial sector strains" around the world, which will impact Australia's growth potential. "Our economic growth is expected to slow from 3.25 per cent in 2022–23 to 1.5 per cent the year after, before recovering to 2.25 per cent in the next," he says. "Despite this, our economy will continue to create jobs, and unemployment is expected to remain low by historical standards — 4.25 per cent in 2023–24, 4.5 per cent the year after."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By social affairs correspondent Norman Hermant Treasurer Jim Chalmers has confirmed the government will deliver energy bill relief in the budget. He says 5.5 million households that are receiving pensions and other government payments, as well as around a million small businesses, will be eligible. There are some reports it could total up to $500 per household. One thing to watch out for is an indication from the government about how this relief will be delivered. Experts such as Nicola Willand, a researcher in housing and sustainability at RMIT University, say the most effective form of delivery will be direct payments from the government into retail energy accounts. Dr Willand also hopes any energy payment isn’t limited to those receiving pensions and Centrelink benefits, “as low-income families just above welfare may miss out”. But while bill relief may be welcome short-term help, it’s not a long-term fix to high energy prices. “It’s going to help a lot, but it’s not going to be a sustainable solution,” Dr Willand said. She believes future spending initiatives should be focused on retrofitting homes to make them more energy efficient. “Homes are not well insulated, they’re not draft-proof, heaters are not efficient. Retrofitting offers continued relief.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Energy relief is coming — but experts waiting for details of who and how

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By social affairs correspondent Norman Hermant and the Specialist Reporting Team’s Leonie Thorne Two hours before the budget drops, the government has come out and confirmed something we basically already knew: JobSeeker payments will be getting a boost. What we didn’t know was which job seekers would benefit and by how much exactly their payments would increase. The 5:00pm announcement has done virtually nothing to clarify that, beyond saying the JobSeeker base rate will increase. About a week ago, we started seeing reports that job seekers over 55 were set to get a boost to their weekly payments. Treasurer Jim Chalmers did not deny those reports. More recently, there have also been leaks suggesting that JobSeeker recipients under 55 could receive modest increases too — about $20 extra per week. The 5pm pre-budget announcement has not confirmed this either. Some advocates, such as Kristin O’Connell from the Antipoverty Centre, believe the later leaks came about after the government was criticised for considering limiting increases to those aged over 55. “The 20 bucks [per week] is a thought bubble,” Ms O’Connell said. “Everything they’ve done in the last week around social security is them being totally taken aback by the reaction.” Advocates also point out that even if these boosts to JobSeeker do materialise, the payment will remain well below the poverty line. Currently, the JobSeeker payment for a single person is $693 a fortnight.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What cost-of-living relief to look out for in the budget

featuredLink.title: 'Help for the most vulnerable': JobSeeker increase confirmed in tonight's federal budget

children.content: By social affairs correspondent Norman Hermant and the Specialist Reporting Team’s Leonie Thorne
Two hours before the budget drops, the government has come out and confirmed something we basically already knew:
JobSeeker payments will be getting a boost.

What we didn’t know was which job seekers would benefit and by how much exactly their payments would increase. The 5:00pm announcement has done virtually nothing to clarify that, beyond saying the JobSeeker base rate will increase.
About a week ago, we started seeing reports that job seekers over 55 were set to get a boost to their weekly payments. Treasurer Jim Chalmers did not deny those reports.

More recently, there have also been leaks suggesting that JobSeeker recipients under 55 could receive modest increases too — about $20 extra per week. The 5pm pre-budget announcement has not confirmed this either.
Some advocates, such as Kristin O’Connell from the Antipoverty Centre, believe the later leaks came about after the government was criticised for considering limiting increases to those aged over 55.
“The 20 bucks [per week] is a thought bubble,” Ms O’Connell said.
“Everything they’ve done in the last week around social security is them being totally taken aback by the reaction.”
Advocates also point out that even if these boosts to JobSeeker do materialise, the payment will remain well below the poverty line.
Currently, the JobSeeker payment for a single person is $693 a fortnight.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's a reasonable question to ask — and if you're anything like me (read: an economics fanatic) you'll have heard plenty of questions being thrown around whether this year's budget is inflationary. Unfortunately it's a bit *too* complicated to answer in short, but let's unpack why you're going to be hearing this phrase and what it means. We know the budget lays out the government's spending intentions for the year (and beyond) and they are hyper-focused on providing cost of living relief because as the name suggests, it's costing us more to live, thanks to higher than average inflation and higher interest rates. The Reserve Bank is using higher interest rates to tackle inflation by deterring us from spending — because the more we spend, the more we add to inflation — but the problem is that the prices of things we need (think housing, energy, food) are also going up. That's partly due to inflation and interest rates, but it's also due to supply shocks thanks to COVID and the Ukraine war, and the price of imported goods being high thanks to the price of our Aussie dollar. Add to that a growing population and housing shortage, and you start to get a sense of how many factors the government is contending with in preparing the budget. Obviously this is a highly simplified version, but it gives us an idea of just how complicated it is. Now when you factor in government spending to keep things ticking over, and how broad a range that is, you can see why the concerns start to mount about an inflationary budget. (Bear in mind, the government also needs to *borrow* money to make all of this happen — and that money needs to be paid back at higher interest rates.) Of course, these things are necessary to keep our country going, and plenty of people argue that the cost of living measures are needed to help people survive — which is why you're hearing Treasurer Jim Chalmers say that they have been carefully considering every measure in the budget to make sure it's not going to make inflation worse. As for how they've reached that balance? We'll hear the justification in less than an hour from now — and we'll also be getting economic experts to unpack it all too.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As we've heard a bit this evening, cost-of-living relief and health will be major features in this year's budget. The ABC's Patricia Karvelas dropped by the blog a little earlier with some of the things she'll be keeping an eye on: Patricia : A federal budget is a big marketing exercise for any government - a chance to make key decisions and choices that demonstrate values and priorities. Journalists are locked up to pore over papers for hours and the government attempts to spin and sell their decisions. And so as we enter Jim Chalmer’s second budget the two political narratives the government has sought to run are that it will engage in fiscal discipline — trying to rewrite the script that Labor is reckless with money — and targeted cost-of-living relief to help the country’s most desperate people. But it’s the things we don’t yet know that will fascinate me. One element will be just how targeted the support for those on welfare will be? Another is housing — it’s the number one water cooler topic in this country. How much will the government invest in tackling some of the entrenched issues. And finally, I will be studying budget paper number 2. That’s the budget paper where you find all the cuts! Finance Minister Katy Gallagher has announced $17.8 billion in “savings” that will contribute to the substantial cost-of-living package, I want to know what will be slashed. That tells a story too — about the things the new government doesn’t value. Looking for more? Patricia Karvelas will be interviewing Anthony Albanese tomorrow at 7:35am on ABC RN Patricia: At 7.35am I’ll be interviewing the Prime Minister which really is a key interview for me - and him. How does he handle some of the curly questions on how all this money being pushed out the door will impact on inflation? And what story about him and his government does he want to tell?
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Patricia Karvelas: 'It's the things we don't know yet that will fascinate me'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you don't know what a lock-up is, don't worry, I'm here to explain. A media lock-up is essentially when a group of journalists are given sensitive information early for the purpose of reporting, but they're locked in a restricted space with no internet to stop any information from leaking early. In the case of the federal budget, there are strict processes where the Treasury approves your attendance ahead of time and officials are there on the day to monitor your activity. We're given the budget papers so that when Treasurer Jim Chalmers reveals this year's budget, we can quickly report on what it means for you. They also take our phones away from us so it's also a bit of an unintentional digital detox.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How does the budget process work?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: With rents reaching record highs in Australia, advocates are hoping to see some relief for low-income households. The ABC's social affairs correspondent Norman Hermant joins us with more: Norman: The government confirmed tonight that rent assistance would increase, so we’re just waiting to see more details. About 1.5 million households receive the Commonwealth Rent Assistance payment. Most of those households are on pensions and benefits. It currently pays a maximum of $157 a fortnight for singles whose rent is between $140 and $350 per week. The Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) has recommended that payment be doubled. In a recent report, ACOSS noted 93 per cent of people renting privately were in rental stress, spending more than 30 per cent of their income on rent. If it is boosted, it could be considered a win for beleaguered renters.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rent assistance boost confirmed — but advocates hope it’s enough

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We know cost-of-living relief is front and centre for this budget for both the government and everyday Aussies, but there's another group who are top of mind for Treasurer Jim Chalmers: small businesses. They're are also going to be watching very closely tonight — they're being squeezed from all sides when it comes to inflation, rising interest rates, high energy prices, supply chain blockages and staff shortages. One major policy coming out of the budget that we already know about that's been targeted towards a million small business owners is the energy rebate, that makes up part of the government's $14.6 billion cost of living package, unveiled yesterday. That will be welcome relief for many small business owners, according to MYOB's chief employee experience officer and government policy lead Helen Lea, who says small businesses are battling a "perfect storm" in the wake of COVID. She's eager for the budget to contain measures that encourage digital innovation — "because we know digital businesses are moer productive," she told RN Breakfast host Patricia Karvelas. As for what other measures there might be for small business owners? We'll have to wait for all to be revealed at 7:30pm. In the meantime, you can hear Ms Lea's full chat below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Not only are under 30s contending with the same cost-of-living pressures being felt across the country, but young Aussies are also hard hit by housing issues. The ABC's political reporter Claudia Long dropped by the blog a little earlier this afternoon to help unpack it all: Claudia: The federal government has its work cut out for it if they plan to use this budget to show young people they're important to Labor. Not only are under 30s contending with the same spiralling cost of living pressures as the rest of the country, young Australians are hard hit by issues around housing. Aside from the often completely out of reach task of buying a home, getting access to rent assistance isn't as straightforward when you're living in a sharehouse — something that isn't confined to under 30's but is certainly more common. And the rising price of pretty much everything hits even harder when you've barely had a chance to establish any savings if you've made it into the workforce. The federal government says they're going to be prioritising the most vulnerable if this budget, at 7:30pm tonight under 30s get to find out whether that includes them.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's in the budget for those under 30?

featuredLink.title: What's in the budget? Here are some of the major measures we know about

children.content: Not only are under 30s contending with the same cost-of-living pressures being felt across the country, but young Aussies are also hard hit by housing issues.
The ABC's political reporter
Claudia Long
dropped by the blog a little earlier this afternoon to help unpack it all:
Claudia:
The federal government has its work cut out for it if they plan to use this budget to show young people they're important to Labor.
Not only are under 30s contending with the same spiralling cost of living pressures as the rest of the country, young Australians are hard hit by issues around housing.

Aside from the often completely out of reach task of buying a home, getting access to rent assistance isn't as straightforward when you're living in a sharehouse — something that isn't confined to under 30's but is certainly more common.
And the rising price of pretty much everything hits even harder when you've barely had a chance to establish any savings if you've made it into the workforce.
The federal government says they're going to be prioritising the most vulnerable if this budget, at 7:30pm tonight under 30s get to find out whether that includes them.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By the specialist teporting team’s Leonie Thorne Last month Disability Services Minister Bill Shorten said the agency responsible for supporting Australians with disability had "lost its way" and needed significant work to ensure its survival. Advocates hope tonight's budget will shed more light on what that "work" involves. The government has already announced a new growth target, which would save more than $50 billion from the NDIS over the next decade. Spending on the scheme was projected to grow about 14 per cent annually over the next decade. The new target will limit that to 8 per cent by 2026. We also know the government is planning to crack down on price-gouging NDIS providerswho overcharge people with disability. "If you have a business model where you are mining someone's supported independent living package for your own interests … sell your business now, because it's not going to be worth much by the time we're finished with you," Mr Shorten told reporters a few weeks ago. The government is also allocating more than $720 million over four years to overhaul the NDIA — the agency which runs the NDIS. What we DON'T know is how the government plans to limit the NDIS's growth, and what changes participants can expect. Disability advocates were shocked and “disappointed” by the growth target, saying they were blindsided by the announcement. Many people in the disability sector are also tired of discourse around reining in the cost of the NDIS, saying it should instead be seen as an investment that has changed the lives of thousands of Australians for the better.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hopes budget will give more detail on 'disappointing' NDIS target

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese yesterday announced an expansion to the single parent payment worth $1.9 billion over the next four years. The ABC's political reporter Tahlia Roy joins us, and says the budget measure will see single parents supported until their youngest dependent turns 14. Tahlia: It is slated to take effect from September 20 and will see an additional 57,000 single parents able to access more than $900 per fortnight. In 2006, the Howard Coalition government changed the eligibility requirements for the payment, lowering the age limit from 16 to eight years old. The decision was grandfathered, so people already on the scheme could remain on it. The Gillard Labor government in 2012 scrapped the grandfathering, moving people with a child older than 8 but younger than 16 onto an unemployment benefit.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: This year's budget brings good news for single parents

featuredLink.title: Single parenting payment cut-off lifted from eight to 14

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government is forecasting a small budget surplus of about $4 billion this financial year, the first in 15 years. The dramatic turnaround from the $36.9 billion deficit projected in October has been driven by high commodity prices, a strong jobs market and a boost in net migration. But Stephen Koukoulas of Market Economics says the federal budget surplus is not expected to last. Stephen: Key commodities that delivered that surging company profit tax have already started to weaken. So that's going to put a hole in future government revenue. And of course, the government is delivering on its election promises from last year. Things like the childcare payments, the increase in the Jobseeker amounts of funding.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Expected budget surplus not expected to last, economist says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By national environment and science reporter Michael Slezak Environment funding has been slashed since 2013. If the government wants to halt the extinction crisis — as it said it did during the election — that needs to change. For context, Australia currently holds the crowning achievement of having more mammal extinctions than any other continent. With that in mind, here are some things we’re keeping an eye out for in tonight’s budget: Environment law reform : This was a central part of the government’s election platform, so we’re looking to see what money goes towards the promised new federal Environmental Protection Authority, and what funding there is to get the environmental laws rewritten Water policy: We’re expecting to see some money for water market reform, and also looking out for funding for a promised review of the Murray Darling Basin Plan Local waterways: Speaking of water, Labor also promised to help clean up local waterways through a new “Urban Rivers and Catchments Program”. We’re looking out for funding for that too Threatened species : Last October, Labor announced a zero extinctions target – so we might see a little bit of extra money go towards some threatened species programs Nature markets: The government also has the big “Nature Repair Market” program, which aims to entice businesses to invest in nature ( read more about the debate here ). We’re expecting to see some funding for that
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Labor’s green election pledges will cost money. Here are the environmental promises to keep an eye out for

children.content: By national environment and science reporter Michael Slezak
Environment funding has been slashed since 2013. If the government wants to halt the extinction crisis — as it said it did during the election — that needs to change.
For context, Australia currently holds the crowning achievement of having more mammal extinctions than any other continent.
With that in mind, here are some things we’re keeping an eye out for in tonight’s budget:
Environment law reform

: This was a central part of the government’s election platform, so we’re looking to see what money goes towards the promised new federal Environmental Protection Authority, and what funding there is to get the environmental laws rewritten
Water policy:
We’re expecting to see some money for water market reform, and also looking out for funding for a promised review of the Murray Darling Basin Plan
Local waterways:
Speaking of water, Labor also promised to help clean up local waterways through a new “Urban Rivers and Catchments Program”. We’re looking out for funding for that too
Threatened species
: Last October, Labor announced a zero extinctions target – so we might see a little bit of extra money go towards some threatened species programs
Nature markets:
The government also has the big “Nature Repair Market” program, which aims to entice businesses to invest in nature (
read more about the debate here
). We’re expecting to see some funding for that

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Making childcare cheaper was one of Anthony Albanese's promises as he went into the last election. So what can we expect for the families in this year's budget? Political reporter Nour Haydar has more: Nour: Anthony Albanese went to the last election with a pledge to “make childcare cheaper” and the changes Labor promised will soon kick in. From July 2023, more than 1.2 million families will be able to access higher childcare subsidies. Under legislation that has already been passed by the parliament, families earning $80,000 or less will get 90 percent of the childcare fees subsidised. Higher subsidy rates will also apply for families earning under $530,000. The government says the changes will benefit 96 per cent of families with a child in early childhood education and care and will cost $55 billion over the next four years to 2026-27.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What can we expect for childcare in the budget?

featuredLink.title: How much will the government's childcare reforms save your family?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The members of media in budget lock-ups are given access to the budget papers about six hours early and spend that time planning our coverage for you. In this case, the lock-up ends at 7.30 pm, when Treasurer Jim Chalmers will deliver his budget speech (and we'll get our internet access back). That time is when I'll be joining you right here to let you know everything I've found out over that six hours. Once his budget speech is over, the treasurer will join the ABC's federal budget television special for an interview. We'll also have an interview with the shadow treasurer, Angus Taylor.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How are the budget papers released?
