liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In healthcare, one of the big things to watch for tonight will be Medicare. The specialist reporting team's Penny Timms is here to help sort through it all: Penny: You might remember that last year, the federal government asked a team of experts to put their heads together and come up with recommendations on how to improve access to primary care and reduce the load on hospitals. Their Strengthening Medicare report, released in February, called for a rethink of how Australia funds primary care and GPs – but did not result in any immediate announcements. At the time, medical experts criticised the report for not including enough detail. So, a lot of people in healthcare will be looking out for the Strengthening Medicare Taskforce’s suggested reforms, and detail on how they will actually happen. The government has talked a big game, and if it doesn't do much, that is likely to be a talking point. During the election, Labor promised close to $1 billion for Medicare and GPs. Of that cash, $750 million was earmarked for the Strengthening Medicare scheme. Now the healthcare sector is waiting to see how it’s spent. One other area to watch is whether this budget will include funding for the promised Centre for Disease Control (CDC), which would better prepare Australia for national health emergencies. Last year’s October “mini-budget” included $3.2 million for “preparations to establish” the CDC. The government and health advocates have already flagged such a centre would require significant additional funding.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will the budget deliver on Medicare promises?

Their Strengthening Medicare report, released in February, called for a rethink of how Australia funds primary care and GPs –

So, a lot of people in healthcare will be looking out for the Strengthening Medicare Taskforce’s suggested reforms, and detail on how they will actually happen. The government has talked a big game, and if it doesn't do much, that is likely to be a talking point.

. Of that cash, $750 million was earmarked for the Strengthening Medicare scheme. Now the healthcare sector is waiting to see how it’s spent.
One other area to watch is whether this budget will include funding for the promised Centre for Disease Control (CDC), which would better prepare Australia for national health emergencies.

Last year’s October “mini-budget” included $3.2 million for “preparations to establish” the CDC. The government and health advocates have already flagged such a centre would require significant additional funding.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal budget is set to include almost $15 billion in cost-of-living relief, amid a year where high inflation continues to take its toll. Speaking to ABC News Breakfast, Finance Minister Katy Gallagher said it's a "significant package". Kate Gallagher : Not just in the scale, but in the reach that we're trying to have with it. So, you know, you'll see different measures as part of that cost of living package. But I think what it shows is that, that really has been front and center our thinking as we finalise the budget... How to provide that sensible and affordable cost of living relief against, you know, an environment of high inflation and that's been certainly a challenge as we've been making our decisions, but people will see the full details of that.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Finance Minister Katy Gallagher on what will be in the budget

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The support is expected to be aimed at pensioners, others on government payments and small businesses. The ABC's political reporter Tom Lowrey joins us, and says it's likely the relief will come in the form of subsidies on energy bills, as opposed to direct payments to households: Tom: For months the federal government has been talking up energy price relief as a “centrepiece” of the budget, and tonight they will finally put some detail to the rhetoric. $1.5bn was pledged in December to help Australians push their power bills down, which would be matched by the states and territories. It’s expected tonight’s package will see roughly 5 million households, and 1 million businesses, receive up to $500 in relief from their power bills. The support is expected to primarily be targeted at pensioners, others on government payments and small businesses. It’s also likely that rather than being paid directly to households, the relief will come as subsidies on energy bills. But the arrangements could become quite complex, as the federal government coordinates its package with various state and territory governments, and energy retailers.

Earlier today, Treasurer Jim Chalmers said the relief is "broader than what has been speculated on." Chalmers: It has a number of elements, it won't all be limited by age or by other distinctions. There will be help for the most vulnerable, but also for middle Australia.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jim Chalmers is speaking with the ABC's David Speers now. Asked if he could guarantee that the budget wouldn't lead to inflation or higher interest rates, the treasurer says "I don't speak on behalf of the Reserve Bank governor". Chalmers: The restraint we've shown and the investments in the supply side of the economy and the way we've targeted and staged our cost of living package is because inflation is the biggest challenge in our economy. This budget has been carefully calibrated and carefully designed to take the pressure off the cost-of-living, not add to inflation.

now.
Asked if he could guarantee that the budget wouldn't lead to inflation or higher interest rates, the treasurer says "I don't speak on behalf of the Reserve Bank governor".
Chalmers:

The restraint we've shown and the investments in the supply side of the economy and the way we've targeted and staged our cost of living package is because inflation is the biggest challenge in our economy.
This budget has been carefully calibrated and carefully designed to take the pressure off the cost-of-living, not add to inflation.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're hearing a lot about the surprise budget surplus of $4.2 billion this year — the first surplus in 15 years — but don't think we're back in black permanently. In its economic outlook, the budget is forecasting a deficit of $13.9 billion in the next financial year of 2023-23 — but that's an improvement of $30.1 billion since October. Those deficits will remain, but will be lower than what they had expected. Here's what the next four years look like in forward estimates: 2023-24 : -$13.9 billion 2024-25 : -$35.1 billion 2025-26 : -$36.6 billion 2026-27 : -$28.5 billion The government doesn't think we'll be completely out of deficit now until 2029-30.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Don't get  too excited by the surplus — the government is expecting more deficits

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coming up — Treasurer Jim Chalmers to face questions about the budget

children.content: He'll be interviewed on the ABC shortly about some of the big announcements to come out of this year's federal budget.
You can watch live using the stream at the top of the page, or follow along on the blog.

image.altText: Collage with blue arrow pointing up, photo cut out of Jim Chalmers, pile of coins and red background.

items.synopsis: A modest increase in unemployment benefits and cheaper healthcare are the centrepieces of a federal budget tasked with helping the nation's most vulnerable at a time when living costs are hurting households.

title.children: Budget lifts JobSeeker and welfare payments as Labor posts a surplus

image.altText: Collage of scrabble letters spelling "W" and "L" and lightbulb, crane, cow, sheep and world icons..

items.synopsis: More money for JobSeeker, bulk billing and spies, but more taxes on smokers and travellers. Find out who is up and who is down in the second federal budget delivered by Treasurer Jim Chalmers.

title.children: Find out if you're among the budget's winners or losers

image.altText: Katy Gallagher and Jim Chalmers walking past the budget tree

items.synopsis: High-vis has been replaced, as a budgetary favourite, with people who for some time have been a bit low-vis — aged care workers, single parents and renters, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: Hi-vis out, low-vis in: Budgets are about choices and these ones are obvious

image.altText: cash lays on a kitchen table beside a cup of tea and a list of bills owing

items.synopsis: The federal budget includes billions in "targeted relief" for the most vulnerable Australians. Here's where the funds are going.

title.children: Cost-of-living relief is costing the budget $14.6 billion. Here's who is eligible for the support

image.altText: A white ute parked on a gravel drive in front of a sandstone work shed with an open roller door.

items.synopsis: Renewable energy and the transition away from fossil fuels are the government's key focus in its assistance to businesses, big and small, but a key small business tax break has been scaled back.

title.children: Business to benefit from energy assistance and renewables investment, but key tax break scaled back

image.altText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers holds a copy of the 2023-24 federal budget strategy and outlook book in front of the media

items.synopsis: Just a few months back, the number crunchers had pencilled in a shortfall of $32 billion for the nation's finances. Suddenly, that's magically transformed into a $4.2 billion surplus, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: The budget is raining cash but it's not all good news

image.altText: Vladmir Putin standing at a lectern, surrounded by people in formal uniforms.

items.synopsis: In a 10-minute speech in Red Square for Victory Day, Mr Putin repeated familiar messages he has delivered many times in the nearly 15 months of Russia's war in Ukraine.

title.children: Putin says a 'real war' is being waged against Russia in Victory Day speech

image.altText: A close-up shot of Terence Kelly being escorted onto a plane.

items.synopsis: The man who snatched four-year-old Cleo Smith from her family's tent at a remote WA campsite and kept her captive for 18 days lodges an appeal against his sentence.

title.children: Cleo Smith's kidnapper Terence Darrell Kelly lodges appeal against jail term

image.altText: Shane walks along carrying documents and wearing sunglasses.

items.synopsis: ACT Director of Public Prosecutions Shane Drumgold called police officers investigating the alleged rape of Brittany Higgins "boofheads", Bruce Lehrmann's lawyer tells an inquiry.

title.children: ACT top prosecutor allegedly labelled police investigators 'boofheads' during Bruce Lehrmann's trial

image.altText: A girl, Alyssa, whose face is blurred, leans on a car in a relaxed way.

items.synopsis: Child safety departments knowingly leave some children with carers who have had serious concerns raised about them, insiders say. In some states, foster and kinship carers don't even have a working with children check.

title.children: When Alyssa's foster brother invited her four-wheel driving she was 'grateful'. Now she knows he was grooming her

image.altText: A man nearing middle age, with short dark hair and a "soul patch" under his lip, sits on a plane with earbuds in his ears.

items.synopsis: Paramedics tell a coronial inquest in NSW that "no-one was interested" in the fact that they were trying to save a man's life in a "weird" scene that an expert witness said "sounded very disturbing".

title.children: Frog poison inquest hears spiritual retreat crowd kept doing yoga while 46yo died

image.altText: View from inside a car of a flooded road.

items.synopsis: Schools are evacuated, roads and parks are flooded and people are being told to prepare to leave homes in case of flash flooding around New Zealand.

title.children: Student missing in a cave as Auckland declares state of emergency

image.altText: Tom Seymour in a suit and a tie speaking on stage at the AFR Summit.

items.synopsis: PricewaterhouseCoopers Australia chief executive Tom Seymour stands down as the consulting firm feels the fallout of a partner betraying the trust of its biggest client: the federal government.

title.children: PwC CEO steps down after tax documents leak scandal

image.altText: A blue sign with white writing on a building that reads "Jenny Craig".

items.synopsis: Administrators are appointed to oversee operations for Jenny Craig Australia and New Zealand less than a week after the US company filed for bankruptcy.

title.children: Jenny Craig Australia enters voluntary administration after US business files for bankruptcy

image.altText: A man holding his phone and walking down the stairs outside a courthouse.

items.synopsis: A jury has found a Van Dung Vu, 37, not guilty of possessing 2.5kg of heroin found in a package of disposable gloves destined for a North Queensland nail salon, with his defence barrister saying he was scammed.

title.children: Baker found not guilty after 2.5kg shipment of heroin delivered to nail salon

image.altText: Short sleeved dark navy police t-shirt, viewed from back of officer in uniform

items.synopsis: Earlier this year, the Palaszczuk government introduced new youth just laws as part of a crackdown. Since the blitz began, the number of children charged with breach of bail can be revealed.

title.children: Dozens of juveniles charged with breach of bail in Queensland's youth crime crackdown

image.altText: A woman in a police uniform standing in front of a microphone next to a man in a blue shirt

items.synopsis: In an effort to bolster Queensland's police numbers, a new recruitment drive will offer a "significant increase" in wages and help you pay off some of your HECS debt.

title.children: First-year police constables in Queensland will earn six figures for a 38-hour week in new recruitment drive

image.altText: A WA Police logo on evidence bags containing large amounts of cash.

items.synopsis: WA police have charged a 36-year-old man with property laundering after seizing $1.8 million in cash during a traffic stop near Southern Cross last week, as investigations continue.

title.children: Police suspect $1.8 million seized in WA traffic stop is the profits of drug trafficking

image.altText: An aerial view of a large crowd, with blurring as of the camera spinning.

items.synopsis: Australians are buying significantly fewer goods at shops and department stores, new Australian Bureau of Statistics data show.

title.children: 'It is here': Official data confirms Australia in a 'consumer recession'

image.altText: A man in a grey and white suit surrounded by photographers

items.synopsis: Sam Bankman-Fried, who has long denied stealing from customers of his FTX cryptocurrency exchange, asks a US judge to throw out criminal charges against him over the now-bankrupt FTX's collapse.

title.children: 'A rush to judgement': FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried urges court to toss charges

image.altText: A black and white pamphlet saying "you and your loved ones are at risk of prescription medicine shortages".

items.synopsis: Patients say they are distressed and disappointed after receiving calls warning of prescription medicine shortages "due to the Albanese Labor government".

title.children: 'Anxiety and mayhem': Pharmacy Guild draws fire over robocalls to 'very vulnerable patients'

image.altText: People in masks walk past a Westpac building in a city.

items.synopsis: Months after postponing the closures because of an ongoing Senate inquiry, the bank has announced that branches in several states will remain open indefinitely.

title.children: Westpac reverses decision to close eight regional branches

image.altText: A man sits at a desk and signs a paper

items.synopsis: The owner of a high-end jeweller in Sydney's CBD is charged with defrauding an insurance company after he allegedly orchestrated his own store's robbery at knifepoint.

title.children: Famous jeweller masterminded robbery on his own Sydney store, police allege

image.altText: A shark with a fish in its mouth.

items.synopsis: Fishers say they're losing more and more fish to sharks. While some are calling for increased fishing quotas or culls, researchers say there's no simple answer.

title.children: 'I lost 125 fish to sharks': Anglers say they're encountering more sharks than ever. So what do the numbers tell us?

image.altText: A woman, wearing the chador, a head-to-toe garment, walks on a sidewalk in front of a mural of Iran leaders.

items.synopsis: Yousef Mehrdad and Sadrollah Fazeli Zare were executed for crimes including blasphemy, insulting the religion of Islam, the prophet and other sanctities, the judiciary's news website reports.

title.children: 'Shocking new low': Iran hangs two men for blasphemy, drawing condemnation from Amnesty International

image.altText: A close up of Dame Edna complete with her iconic sunglasses and purple hair.

items.synopsis: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews confirms Barry Humphries's family has chosen Sydney as the city for the entertainer's service, despite him being born in Melbourne.

title.children: Barry Humphries to be farewelled in Sydney instead of home city Melbourne

image.altText: A picture of pedestrians walking over a bridge in Melbourne

items.synopsis: One of the world's foremost experts on cities has warned Australia risks "sleepwalking into a long-term loss of productivity"  but not everyone agrees.

title.children: Australian cities are falling behind the rest of the world when it comes to productivity. Here's why

image.altText: A vehicle drives across a polar landscape as a plane flies overhead

items.synopsis: Experts believe knowledge sharing and collaboration between countries and research organisations are the best ways to prevent the outbreak of future pandemics.

title.children: A 50,000-year-old virus was found frozen in ice last year. Researchers don't know what could happen if it spread
